resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:173702767</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:WHi</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>WHA (Radio station : Madison, Wis.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Wisconsin communities radio broadcasts, 1951.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Tape recordings and transcriptions of a series of documentary radio programs produced in 1951 by Radio Station WHA, concerning various communities in Wisconsin: Door County, Pulaski, Beloit, Green County, Oshkosh, Stoughton, Sauk Prairie, Eau Claire, County, Vilas County, Wausau, West Bend,  and La Crosse. The radio programs include interviews with residents, historical background, and profiles of the current communities. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Wisconsin communities radio broadcasts, 1951.
resource.abstract: Tape recordings and transcriptions of a series of documentary radio programs produced in 1951 by Radio Station WHA, concerning various communities in Wisconsin: Door County, Pulaski, Beloit, Green County, Oshkosh, Stoughton, Sauk Prairie, Eau Claire, County, Vilas County, Wausau, West Bend,  and La Crosse. The radio programs include interviews with residents, historical background, and profiles of the current communities.
resource.displayEntry: WHA (Radio station : Madison, Wis.). Wisconsin communities radio broadcasts, 1951.

resourceRelations.content: WHA (Radio station : Madison, Wis.). Wisconsin communities radio broadcasts, 1951.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:315826164</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-WHSAR</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Alexander, Edward P. (Edward Porter), 1907- .</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Wisconsin's Yesterdays, undated.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Original manuscript (360 pages) for a proposed book entitled "Wisconsin's Yesterdays," written by Edward P. Alexander, a former director of the State Historical Society of Wisconsin. Framework for the book is taken from radio station WHA College of the Air program of the same name. The author appeared on "Wisconsin's Yesterdays" in 1942-43 to give a series of radio lectures on the history of Wisconsin and the manuscript is based on these lectures and is intended to be a broad introduction to Wisconsin history, from ancient times to the modern era. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Wisconsin Historical Society Archives</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Wisconsin's Yesterdays, undated.
resource.abstract: Original manuscript (360 pages) for a proposed book entitled "Wisconsin's Yesterdays," written by Edward P. Alexander, a former director of the State Historical Society of Wisconsin. Framework for the book is taken from radio station WHA College of the Air program of the same name. The author appeared on "Wisconsin's Yesterdays" in 1942-43 to give a series of radio lectures on the history of Wisconsin and the manuscript is based on these lectures and is intended to be a broad introduction to Wisconsin history, from ancient times to the modern era.
resource.displayEntry: Alexander, Edward P. (Edward Porter), 1907- . Wisconsin's Yesterdays, undated.

resourceRelations.content: Alexander, Edward P. (Edward Porter), 1907- . Wisconsin's Yesterdays, undated.

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Correspondence collected by Penn, a broadcast historian, concerning the early history of WHA, the radio station of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and the work of physicist Earl M. Terry. Also includes an address by Terry, circa 1925; a WHA program log, 1922-1925; and a history of the station by Harold Engel. </abstract>

                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:173700116</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:WHi</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Jansky, Cyril Moreau, 1895-1975.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1917-1974.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers of a radio pioneer and consulting engineer consisting of correspondence and memoranda; minutes; interviews, speeches and writings (some also in recorded form); reports; reference material; sound recordings; and films. Records of Jansky & Bailey, consulting engineers, consists of incomplete administrative records and client reports by Jansky and others concerning station coverage and the marine uses of radio.  Particularly extensive are reports, and films concerning work for Lake Carriers Association.  Also included is an extensive file of speeches and articles, financial and legal papers, information on various organizations and societies to which Jansky belonged, and miscellaneous family correspondence. The processed portion is summarized above and is described in the register. Additional photographic accessions are described below. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers, 1917-1974.
resource.abstract: Papers of a radio pioneer and consulting engineer consisting of correspondence and memoranda; minutes; interviews, speeches and writings (some also in recorded form); reports; reference material; sound recordings; and films. Records of Jansky & Bailey, consulting engineers, consists of incomplete administrative records and client reports by Jansky and others concerning station coverage and the marine uses of radio.  Particularly extensive are reports, and films concerning work for Lake Carriers Association.  Also included is an extensive file of speeches and articles, financial and legal papers, information on various organizations and societies to which Jansky belonged, and miscellaneous family correspondence. The processed portion is summarized above and is described in the register. Additional photographic accessions are described below.
resource.extent: 6.0 c.f. (15 archives boxes and 1 flat box),2 films, and15 tape recordings; plusadditions of 182 photographs,46 negatives, and36 transparencies.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:173699528</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:WHi</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Lighty, William H.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers of William Lighty, a pioneer in the field of adult education who was on the administrative staff of the Extension Division of the University of Wisconsin from 1906 to 1937 and exerted a marked influence on its development.  The bulk of the collection derives from the period between 1910 and 1930 and is composed of Lighty's personal, business, and professional correspondence; his articles and speeches; and records of the Extension Division.  His papers for the period prior to 1906 contain material on his early education and teaching experiences in Pennsylvania; on his interest in the ethical culture movement, particularly in St. Louis; and on a summer camp for boys which he operated near Spooner, Wis.  On tape are his recollections of his work in the Extension Division. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers.
resource.abstract: Papers of William Lighty, a pioneer in the field of adult education who was on the administrative staff of the Extension Division of the University of Wisconsin from 1906 to 1937 and exerted a marked influence on its development.  The bulk of the collection derives from the period between 1910 and 1930 and is composed of Lighty's personal, business, and professional correspondence; his articles and speeches; and records of the Extension Division.  His papers for the period prior to 1906 contain material on his early education and teaching experiences in Pennsylvania; on his interest in the ethical culture movement, particularly in St. Louis; and on a summer camp for boys which he operated near Spooner, Wis.  On tape are his recollections of his work in the Extension Division.
resource.extent: 20.5 c.f. (99 archives boxes and 3 card file boxes) and16 tape recordings; plusadditions of 1.6 c.f. and3 tape recordings.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:145778943</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:WHi</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>McCarty, Harold B. 1901-1987.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Harold B. McCarty papers, 1922-1986.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers of Harold McCarty, long-term station director of WHA Radio in Madison, Wisconsin. McCarty served WHA from 1929 to 1966, first as station manager, then as director of the Wisconsin State Broadcasting System, continuing on as Executive Director of the Wisconsin Radio and Television Council. McCarty is well known for his contributions to the development of the radio program Wisconsin School of the Air (WSA), but he was also a leading proponent of non-commercial radio, he served as president of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters, and published widely on the subject of educational radio. The collection documents primarily the development of educational radio and television in the state of Wisconsin and nationally. It also documents the organization, operation, and management of WHA, the relationship between WHA and the University, radio programming and listeners' responses, and aspects of the State Radio Council and the National Association of Educational Broadcasters. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Harold B. McCarty papers, 1922-1986.
resource.abstract: Papers of Harold McCarty, long-term station director of WHA Radio in Madison, Wisconsin. McCarty served WHA from 1929 to 1966, first as station manager, then as director of the Wisconsin State Broadcasting System, continuing on as Executive Director of the Wisconsin Radio and Television Council. McCarty is well known for his contributions to the development of the radio program Wisconsin School of the Air (WSA), but he was also a leading proponent of non-commercial radio, he served as president of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters, and published widely on the subject of educational radio. The collection documents primarily the development of educational radio and television in the state of Wisconsin and nationally. It also documents the organization, operation, and management of WHA, the relationship between WHA and the University, radio programming and listeners' responses, and aspects of the State Radio Council and the National Association of Educational Broadcasters.
resource.displayEntry: McCarty, Harold B. 1901-1987. Harold B. McCarty papers, 1922-1986.

resourceRelations.content: McCarty, Harold B. 1901-1987. Harold B. McCarty papers, 1922-1986.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Mass Media and Culture</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Special Collections, University of Maryland Libraries, Hornbake Library, College Park, MD 20742. Tel: 301-405-9212, Fax: 301-314-2709, Email: askhornbake@umd.edu</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Lamb, Luke F.</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Luke F. Lamb Papers</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1964-1992</unitdate>
                  <unitdate>1964-1969</unitdate>
                  <physdesc>0.50 linear foot</physdesc>
                  <unitid>NPBA 92-99</unitid>
                  <physloc>Room 3210 (Showcase Room):70:B:Room 3210 (Showcase Room) 70 : B : </physloc>
                  <abstract>Luke F. Lamb was the associate director of ITV (Instructional Television) at the University of Missouri.  In the early 1960s, Lamb was the director of educational media for the Division of Continuing Education of the Oregon State System of Higher Education, representing stations KOAP and KOAC (Corvallis/Portland).  In December 1964, Lamb was nominated to National Association of Educational Broadcasters' (NAEB) Television Board of Directors.  Starting in February 1966, he chaired NAEB's Standing Network Committee of the NAEB and was chair of the Network Committee by November.  From 1967 to 1968, Lamb presided over the Western Education Network, which had its host station at KVIE, Sacramento, California.  In 1968, Lamb started his association with the University of Wisconsin as director of Educational Communications with University Extension.  In September 1972, he became dean of Educational Communications and chair of the Wisconsin Educational Communications Board.  Currently, Lamb is Director of Broadcasting, Wisconsin Educational Communications Board and Director of the Extension Communications Division, University of Wisconsin-Extension.  The collection contains early Western Educational Network files from 1964 to 1968.  It also contains the 50th anniversary publication of station WHA, University of Wisconsin, and the 75th anniversary publication commemorating Wisconsin Public Broadcasting.</abstract>
                  <abstract>Luke F. Lamb was the associate director of ITV (Instructional Television) at the University of Missouri.  In the early 1960s, Lamb was the director of educational media for the Division of Continuing Education of the Oregon State System of Higher Education, representing stations KOAP and KOAC (Corvallis/Portland).  In December 1964, Lamb was nominated to National Association of Educational Broadcasters' (NAEB) Television Board of Directors.  Starting in February 1966, he chaired NAEB's Standing Network Committee of the NAEB and was chair of the Network Committee by November.  From 1967 to 1968, Lamb presided over the Western Education Network, which had its host station at KVIE, Sacramento, California.  In 1968, Lamb started his association with the University of Wisconsin as director of Educational Communications with University Extension.  In September 1972, he became dean of Educational Communications and chair of the Wisconsin Educational Communications Board.  Currently, Lamb is Director of Broadcasting, Wisconsin Educational Communications Board and Director of the Extension Communications Division, University of Wisconsin-Extension.  The collection contains early Western Educational Network files from 1964 to 1968.  It also contains the 50th anniversary publication of station WHA, University of Wisconsin, and the 75th anniversary publication commemorating Wisconsin Public Broadcasting.</abstract>
                  <abstract>Luke F. Lamb was the associate director of ITV (Instructional Television) at the University of Missouri.  In the early 1960s, Lamb was the director of educational media for the Division of Continuing Education of the Oregon State System of Higher Education, representing stations KOAP and KOAC (Corvallis/Portland). In 1968, Lamb started his association with the University of Wisconsin as director of Educational Communications with University Extension.  In September 1972, he became dean of Educational Communications and chair of the Wisconsin Educational Communications Board.  Currently, Lamb is Director of Broadcasting, Wisconsin Educational Communications Board and Director of the Extension Communications Division, University of Wisconsin-Extension.  The collection contains early Western Educational Network files from 1964 to 1968.  It also contains the 50th anniversary publication of station WHA, University of Wisconsin, and the 75th anniversary publication commemorating Wisconsin Public Broadcasting.</abstract>
                  <abstract>Luke F. Lamb was the associate director of ITV (Instructional Television) at the University of Missouri.  In the early 1960s, Lamb was the director of educational media for the Division of Continuing Education of the Oregon State System of Higher Education, representing stations KOAP and KOAC (Corvallis/Portland).  In December 1964, Lamb was nominated to National Association of Educational Broadcasters' (NAEB) Television Board of Directors.  Starting in February 1966, he chaired NAEB's Standing Network Committee of the NAEB and was chair of the Network Committee by November.  From 1967 to 1968, Lamb presided over the Western Education Network, which had its host station at KVIE, Sacramento, California.  In 1968, Lamb started his association with the University of Wisconsin as director of Educational Communications with University Extension.  In September 1972, he became dean of Educational Communications and chair of the Wisconsin Educational Communications Board.  Currently, Lamb is Director of Broadcasting, Wisconsin Educational Communications Board and Director of the Extension Communications Division, University of Wisconsin-Extension.  The collection contains early Western Educational Network files from 1964 to 1968.  It also contains the 50th anniversary publication of station WHA, University of Wisconsin, and the 75th anniversary publication commemorating Wisconsin Public Broadcasting.</abstract>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Luke F. Lamb Papers 1964-1992 1964-1969
resource.abstract: Luke F. Lamb was the associate director of ITV (Instructional Television) at the University of Missouri.  In the early 1960s, Lamb was the director of educational media for the Division of Continuing Education of the Oregon State System of Higher Education, representing stations KOAP and KOAC (Corvallis/Portland).  In December 1964, Lamb was nominated to National Association of Educational Broadcasters' (NAEB) Television Board of Directors.  Starting in February 1966, he chaired NAEB's Standing Network Committee of the NAEB and was chair of the Network Committee by November.  From 1967 to 1968, Lamb presided over the Western Education Network, which had its host station at KVIE, Sacramento, California.  In 1968, Lamb started his association with the University of Wisconsin as director of Educational Communications with University Extension.  In September 1972, he became dean of Educational Communications and chair of the Wisconsin Educational Communications Board.  Currently, Lamb is Director of Broadcasting, Wisconsin Educational Communications Board and Director of the Extension Communications Division, University of Wisconsin-Extension.  The collection contains early Western Educational Network files from 1964 to 1968.  It also contains the 50th anniversary publication of station WHA, University of Wisconsin, and the 75th anniversary publication commemorating Wisconsin Public Broadcasting. Luke F. Lamb was the associate director of ITV (Instructional Television) at the University of Missouri.  In the early 1960s, Lamb was the director of educational media for the Division of Continuing Education of the Oregon State System of Higher Education, representing stations KOAP and KOAC (Corvallis/Portland).  In December 1964, Lamb was nominated to National Association of Educational Broadcasters' (NAEB) Television Board of Directors.  Starting in February 1966, he chaired NAEB's Standing Network Committee of the NAEB and was chair of the Network Committee by November.  From 1967 to 1968, Lamb presided over the Western Education Network, which had its host station at KVIE, Sacramento, California.  In 1968, Lamb started his association with the University of Wisconsin as director of Educational Communications with University Extension.  In September 1972, he became dean of Educational Communications and chair of the Wisconsin Educational Communications Board.  Currently, Lamb is Director of Broadcasting, Wisconsin Educational Communications Board and Director of the Extension Communications Division, University of Wisconsin-Extension.  The collection contains early Western Educational Network files from 1964 to 1968.  It also contains the 50th anniversary publication of station WHA, University of Wisconsin, and the 75th anniversary publication commemorating Wisconsin Public Broadcasting. Luke F. Lamb was the associate director of ITV (Instructional Television) at the University of Missouri. In December 1964, Lamb was nominated to National Association of Educational Broadcasters' (NAEB) Television Board of Directors.  Starting in February 1966, he chaired NAEB's Standing Network Committee of the NAEB and was chair of the Network Committee by November.  From 1967 to 1968, Lamb presided over the Western Education Network, which had its host station at KVIE, Sacramento, California.  In 1968, Lamb started his association with the University of Wisconsin as director of Educational Communications with University Extension.  In September 1972, he became dean of Educational Communications and chair of the Wisconsin Educational Communications Board.  Currently, Lamb is Director of Broadcasting, Wisconsin Educational Communications Board and Director of the Extension Communications Division, University of Wisconsin-Extension.  The collection contains early Western Educational Network files from 1964 to 1968.  It also contains the 50th anniversary publication of station WHA, University of Wisconsin, and the 75th anniversary publication commemorating Wisconsin Public Broadcasting. Luke F. Lamb was the associate director of ITV (Instructional Television) at the University of Missouri.  In the early 1960s, Lamb was the director of educational media for the Division of Continuing Education of the Oregon State System of Higher Education, representing stations KOAP and KOAC (Corvallis/Portland).  In December 1964, Lamb was nominated to National Association of Educational Broadcasters' (NAEB) Television Board of Directors.  Starting in February 1966, he chaired NAEB's Standing Network Committee of the NAEB and was chair of the Network Committee by November.  From 1967 to 1968, Lamb presided over the Western Education Network, which had its host station at KVIE, Sacramento, California.  In 1968, Lamb started his association with the University of Wisconsin as director of Educational Communications with University Extension.  In September 1972, he became dean of Educational Communications and chair of the Wisconsin Educational Communications Board.  Currently, Lamb is Director of Broadcasting, Wisconsin Educational Communications Board and Director of the Extension Communications Division, University of Wisconsin-Extension.  The collection contains early Western Educational Network files from 1964 to 1968.  It also contains the 50th anniversary publication of station WHA, University of Wisconsin, and the 75th anniversary publication commemorating Wisconsin Public Broadcasting.
